message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of severe headaches on the left forehead and eye, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea suggest Cluster headache. The use of indomethacin is also a common treatment for Cluster headache. The other options do not fit with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Cluster headache, which is often associated with autonomic symptoms such as tearing, rhinorrhea, and ptosis. Medication overuse headache is unlikely because the patient has not had relief even after taking indomethacin. Giant cell arteritis can cause headaches and temporal artery tenderness but does not cause autonomic symptoms. Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sharp, stabbing pain in the face and does not cause autonomic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the severe pain on one side of the head and around the eye, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea are typical of cluster headaches. The patient’s history of smoking and stressful work are also risk factors. The lack of relief from indomethacin and localized tenderness along the right supraspinatus muscle suggest that other options are less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The severe headache on the left forehead and eye, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea suggest a cluster headache. The fact that the patient has had similar symptoms last summer also supports this diagnosis. The localized tenderness along the right supraspinatus muscle may be an incidental finding. Giant cell arteritis would have other signs and symptoms like scalp tenderness and jaw claudication. Medication overuse headache is unlikely since the patient has only been taking indomethacin for 24 hours. Trigeminal neuralgia typically presents with more severe pain and is often triggered by touch or movement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe headache on one side, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea are suggestive of cluster headache. The history of smoking and stressful job may also contribute to the development of cluster headaches. Indomethacin is a first-line treatment for cluster headaches, so the lack of relief with this medication does not rule out the diagnosis. None of the other options present with the specific cluster headache symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe headache on one side, drooping of the eyelid and tearing of the eye, suggest cluster headache. The lack of relief from indomethacin distinguishes it from medication overuse headache. The localized tenderness along the supraspinatus muscle suggests involvement of the sphenopalatine ganglion, which is commonly affected in cluster headache. Giant cell arteritis and trigeminal neuralgia typically have different symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe headaches on the left forehead and eye, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea, suggest that the most likely diagnosis is cluster headache. Indomethacin is not typically effective for cluster headaches, but it is effective for hemicrania continua, which sometimes resembles cluster headache. The tenderness along the right supraspinatus muscle is not relevant to the diagnosis of cluster headache. The absence of any visual problems or jaw pain rules out giant cell arteritis and trigeminal neuralgia. There is no evidence to suggest medication overuse headache.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of severe headaches on one side of the head, with drooping of the eyelid, tearing of the eye, and rhinorrhea, suggest that he is experiencing a cluster headache. This type of headache is often associated with stress and smoking. The fact that the patient has not responded to indomethacin also suggests that this is not a medication overuse headache. Giant cell arteritis and trigeminal neuralgia have different symptom profiles and are less likely diagnoses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, with severe headaches on the left forehead and eye, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea are consistent with cluster headache. Medication overuse headache usually occurs with excessive use of analgesics, and there is no mention of such. Giant cell arteritis is associated with fever, sweating, and tender scalp, which is not indicated in the question. Trigeminal neuralgia usually causes sharp, shooting pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe headaches on the left forehead and eye, drooping of the left eyelid, tearing of the left eye, and rhinorrhea are suggestive of Cluster headaches. Medication overuse headache is unlikely since the patient has not found relief with indomethacin. Giant cell arteritis presents with headaches on both sides, scalp tenderness, and visual changes. Trigeminal neuralgia presents with severe paroxysmal pain limited to the distribution of one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The tenderness along the supraspinatus muscle is not relevant for this diagnosis.
